awd_titl_txt: Liquid impingement dynamics on superheated superhydrophobic surfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Characterizing heat transfer from a solid plate to a liquid is important in multiple applications where cooling, condensation, or cleaning properties are necessary. Superhydrophobic surfaces can be self-cleaning and thus present an immediate advantage for their use when in contact with liquids. Water will sit atop the micro/nano structures, leaving an air gap in between the structures and allowing for water to bead up almost completely into a ball on the surface. The water will then roll from the surface and thus it becomes self-cleaning. Although the liquid dynamics of impingement on a superhydrophobic surface are fairly well known, the understanding of heat transfer from these surfaces with micro-scale air gaps to an impinging liquid is not well characterized. Impinging liquids are able to remove heat by the constant replenishing of new, cooler liquid. This study will explore the capability of impinging water droplets or impinging water jets to remove heat from a superhydrophobic surface while still effectively being self cleaning. 

Superhydrophobic surfaces are generated by combining microscale structuring and a hydrophobic coating such that liquids are often only in contact with a fraction of the solid surface. Impinging processes are rich in fundamental fluid flow and thermal transport physics and represent an excellent test bed to consider with superhydrophobic surfaces since superhydrophobicity exerts enormous influence on the liquid-solid surface tension, which is dominant in impinging processes. It is expected that thermal transport physics of liquid impingement on superhydrophobic surfaces will experience greater departure from classical behavior than has been observed hydrodynamically. The objectives of this work are to characterize the transport for: 1) impinging droplets (normal and oblique impingement angles), and 2) liquid jet impingement (normal and oblique impingement). The proposed research plan includes coupled experimental and analytical approaches. The processes that will be explored have significance in next generation high efficiency condensers, desalinization processes, self-cleaning surfaces, and easily maintained spray cooling systems.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
Superhydrophobic surfaces are extremely water-repellant and provide a plethora of useful capabilities, one of the most prominent of which is self-cleaning. These are often seen as spray coatings which can be applied to a surface and when water or even mud meets the surface it is immediately repelled. This scenario is made possible by two mechanisms on the surface: a micro- or nano-structure and a chemically hydrophobic coating. With these mechanisms working together, water will sit atop the surface structures, with air gaps in-between, significantly increasing the propensity of water to bead-up on the surface.

 

Self-cleaning is not the only interesting dynamic superhydrophobic surfaces display. Water can slip over the air-filled gaps reducing friction, drops bounce with a high coefficient of restitution, and jets breakup instead of forming a downstream hydraulic jump. In addition to the interesting hydrodynamics observed on superhydrophobic surfaces, the heat transfer through them is fascinating as well. On these surfaces liquid is only in contact with the small surface area corresponding to the tops of the structures and the bulk of the liquid is in contact with the air in the cavities, which does not transfer heat well. Our work has quantified the reduction in heat transfer from impinging drops and jets for use in applications where insulation is key, such as in space, where these surfaces can provide an alternative to classic, larger insulating materials.

 

When phase change occurs, heat transfer dynamics are even more significantly altered by contact with a superhydrophobic surface. For example, during condensation, due to the greater number of nucleation sites and the propensity of drops to roll away from the surface, heat transfer is enhanced. Yet in boiling scenarios, water vapor is generated and can combine with the air in the cavities and lift the liquid further off the surface and nearly halt all heat transfer. During liquid impingement events the air cavities may be filled by the liquid increasing the contact and subsequently the heat transfer. The dynamics are fascinating and not well understood. An aspect of the research here focused on understanding the dynamics of heat transfer and thermal atomization during liquid impingement on superhydrophbic surfaces.

 

Atomization is the breakup of small drops into much smaller droplets. Thermal atomization occurs when water boils. At the surface of the boiling water, vapor bubbles are released, breaking the surface tension locally, and causing a spray of smaller droplets. The amount of atomization is often used as an estimate for the heat transfer that has occurred, since boiling is a precursor to atomization. Yet on superhydrophobic surfaces the vapor need not escape from the top surface of the water, but can travel through the structures underneath the surface, mitigating or even arresting atomization. A mathematical model has been generated to describe the vapor generation and estimate atomization based on vapor generation and relative escape routes. It compares well with experiments performed as a part of this work.

 

Our work allows estimation of heat transfer and atomization dynamics for a range of types of superhydrophobic surfaces and impact conditions. The structure size, shape, and spacing affects the heat transfer and atomization, though, not only the relative contact. A temperature jump length (associated with the apparent difference in temperature between the surface and liquid in contact) is used to combine the effects of the structure design and spacing and is found to capture the dynamics well. This knowledge allows use of these surfaces in a variety of applications ranging from diesel fuel, clean water condensation from humid air, and insulative materials.

 

Graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 students were all involved in this work and learned new ideas and techniques. Over the course of the research, eight undergraduate students (one female) were heavily involved in the experimental design, testing, and analysis. They also learned about a range of fluid-thermal flows, in addition to those needed specifically for this research, as a part of lab meetings and one on one mentoring. Six graduate students were also trained in the methods of microfabrication and micro-structure characterization techniques. These include deep reactive ion etching, wet etching, scanning electron microscope training, and profilometer training. Each of the students have used design principles to create or enhance an experimental apparatus. They have learned high speed imaging techniques, including infrared imaging. These students, along with the PI, also designed and implemented outreach activities for K-12 and early college students. These included demonstrations in the laboratory as well as presentations for the community to introduce them to interesting science topics and instill an excitement for education.

 


Last Modified: 01/16/2024
Modified by: Julie Crockett
